z:row.TitlePrimary: Three-dimensional modeling of complex fusion devices using CAD-MCNPX interface
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LA GRANGE PK; 555 N KENSINGTON AVENUE, LA GRANGE PK, IL 60526 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Sandia Natl Labs, Albuquerque, NM 87185 USA. Univ Calif San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093 USA.; Wang, MK, Univ Wisconsin, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; mengkuow@cae.wisc.edu titautg@sandia.gov henderson(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: MCNPX's [1] geometric modeling capabilities are limited to Boolean combinations of primitive geometric shapes. These capabilities are not sufficient for simulating particle transport in stellerators, whose geometric models are quite complex. We describe a CAD based implementation of MCNPX where a CAD geometry engine is used directly for solid model representation and evaluation. The application of this code, to calculating the neutron wall loading distribution (Gamma) in the Z and toroidal directions for the ARIES-CS[2] design, is described.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BLACKER TD, 1994, SAND941100 BRIESMEISTER JF, 1997, MCNP GEN MONTE CARLO ELGUEBALY L, COMMUNICATION NAJMABADI F, 2004, EXPLORATION COMPACT TAUTGES TJ, 2001, ENG COMPUT-GERMANY, V17, P299 WATERS LS, 1999, TPOE83GUGX00001; NR: 6; TC: 2; J9: FUSION SCI TECHNOL; PG: 5; GA: 921GU

z:row.TitlePrimary: CGM: A geometry interface for mesh generation, analysis and other applications
z:row.Keyword: adaptive mesh refinement|componentization|geometry|solid modeling|Computer Science, Interdisciplinary Applications|Engineering, Mechanical
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 175 FIFTH AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10010 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Sandia Natl Labs, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Tautges, TJ, Sandia Natl Labs, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Geometry modeling has recently emerged as a commodity capability. Several geometry modeling engines are available which provide largely the same capability, and most high-end CAD systems provide access to their geometry through APIs. However, subtle differences exist between these modelers, both at the syntax level and in the underlying topological models. A modeler-independent interface to geometry bridges these differences, allowing applications to be developed in a true modeler- independent manner. The Common Geometry Module, or CGM, provides such an interface to geometry. At the most basic level, CGM translates geometry function calls to access geometry in its native format. To smooth over topological differences between modelers, and to allow modeler-independent modification of topology, CGM maintains its own topology datastructure. CGM also provides functionality not found in most modelers, like support for non-manifold topology, and alternative representations, including facer-based and 'virtual' geometry. CGM is designed to be extensible, allowing applications to derive application-specific capabilities from topological entities defined in CGM. The CUBIT Mesh Generation Toolkit has been modified to work directly with CGM. CGM is also designed to simplify the implementation of other solid model-based or alternative representations of geometry. Ports to Solid Works and Pro/Engineer are underway. CGM is also being used as the foundation for parallel mesh generation, and is being used for geometry support in several advanced finite element analysis codes.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *PTC INC, APPL PROGR TOOLK *SOL CORP, SOL API *SPAT TECHN INC, ACIS 3D TOOLK *SPAT TECHN INC, MOR 3D MOD INT PROBL *STRUCT DYN RES CO, OP I DEAS ARMSTRONG C, 2000, DJINN GEOMETRIC INTE BLACKER T, 1994, SAND941100 SAND NAT, V1 BROWN DH, 1998, CAX MODELING APIS WH CHEW LP, 1997, TRENDS UNSTRUCTURED, P89 DECOUGNY HL, 1996, ENG COMPUT, V12, P94 GAMMA E, 1994, DESIGN PATTERNS ELEM HAIMES R, 1998, P 6 INT C NUM GRID G HUGHES HG, 1997, TOP M NUCL APPL ACC KRAFTCHECK J, 2000, THESIS U WISCONSIN M LOBER RR, 1997, SAND970545 SAND NAT OWEN SJ, 2000, UNPUB 3 S TRENDS UNS PANTHAKI M, 1997, P 6 INT MESH ROUNDT SAIFULLAH S, OLE DESIGN MODELING SHEPHARD MS, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V47, P169 SHEPHERD J, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P277 SHOSTKO A, 1995, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V38, P905 TAUTGES TJ, 2000, P 9 INT MESH ROUNDT TAUTGES TJ, 2001, COMMON GEOMETRY MODU TAUTGES TJ, 2001, GEOMETRY ATTRIBUTES WHITE DR, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT WHITE DR, 2000, COMMUNICATION WHITE DR, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P127; NR: 27; TC: 3; J9: ENG COMPUT; PG: 16; GA: 495UH

z:row.TitlePrimary: The generation of hexahedral meshes for assembly geometry: survey and progress
z:row.Keyword: mesh generation|hexahedral|quadrilateral|geometry decomposition|MEDIAL SURFACE SUBDIVISION|FINITE-ELEMENT|ALGORITHM|SOLIDS|MORPH|EDGES|VOLUMES|Engineering, Multidisciplinary|Mathematics, Interdisciplinary Applications
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX PO19 1UD, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Sandia Corp, Sandia Natl Labs, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Tautges, TJ, Univ Wisconsin, Sandia Corp, Sandia Natl Labs, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The finite element method is being used today to model component assemblies in a wide variety of application areas, including structural mechanics, fluid simulations, and others. Generating hexahedral meshes for these assemblies usually requires the use of geometry decomposition, with different meshing algorithms applied to different regions. While the primary motivation for this approach remains the lack of an automatic, reliable all-hexahedral meshing algorithm, requirements in mesh quality and mesh configuration for typical analyses are also factors. For these reasons, this approach is also sometimes required when producing other types of unstructured meshes. This paper will review progress to date in automating many parts of the hex meshing process, which has halved the time to produce all-hex meshes for large assemblies. Particular issues which have been exposed due to this progress will also be discussed, along with their applicability to the general unstructured meshing problem. Published in 2001 by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Feature based hex meshing methodology: feature recognition and volume decomposition
z:row.Keyword: feature recognition|FEA|solid modeling|hexahedral meshing|volume decomposition|MEDIAL SURFACE SUBDIVISION|ELEMENT MESHES|GENERATION|ALGORITHM|SOLIDS|EDGES|Computer Science, Software Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, OXON, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, I CARVE Lab, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Sandia Natl Labs, Livermore, CA 94550 USA.; Lu, Y, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, I CARVE Lab, 1500 Engn Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Considerable progress has been made on automatic hexahedral mesh generation in recent years. A few automated meshing algorithms (e.g. mapping, submapping, sweeping) have proven to be very reliable on certain classes of geometry. While it is always worth pursuing general algorithms viable on arbitrary geometry, a combination of the well-established algorithms is ready to take on classes of complicated geometry. By partitioning the entire geometry into meshable pieces matched with appropriate meshing algorithms, the original geometry becomes meshable and may achieve better mesh quality. Each meshable portion is recognized as a meshing feature. This paper, which is a part of the feature based meshing methodology, presents the work on shape recognition and volume decomposition to automatically decompose a CAD model into hex meshable volumes. There are four phases in this approach: Feature Determination to extract decomposition features; Cutting Surfaces Generation to form the cutting surfaces; Body Decomposition to get the imprinted volumes; and Meshing Algorithm Assignment to match volumes decomposed with appropriate meshing algorithms. This paper focuses on describing feature determination and volume decomposition; the last part has been described in another paper. The feature determination procedure is based on the CLoop feature recognition algorithm that is extended to be more general. Some decomposition and meshing results are demonstrated in the final section. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *SPAT TECHN INC, 1996, ACIS GEOM MOD APPL G ARMSTRONG CG, 1995, P 4 INT MESH ROUNDT BENZLEY SE, 1995, P 4 INT MESH ROUNDT, P179 BLACKER TD, 1988, 88WACIE4 ASME BLACKER TD, 1989, P ASME COMP ENG C BLACKER TD, 1994, CUBIT MESH GENERATIO, V1 BLACKER TD, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT, P13 CHAZELLE BM, 1981, S THEOR COMP MILW, P70 COOK WA, 1983, COMPUTERS MECH ENG, V1, P67 FOLWELL NT, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT GADH R, 1992, COMPUT AIDED DESIGN, V24, P583 HOHMEYER ME, 1995, P 4 INT MESH ROUNDT, P129 KNUPP P, 1998, PERSONAL EXPERIENCE KNUPP P, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG KNUPP PM, 1999, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V45, P37 KYPRIANOU L, 1980, THESIS U CAMBRIDGE LIU SS, 1997, DEFINITION EXTRACTIO LIU SS, 1998, ASME T, V120, P728 LU Y, 1999, P 25 DES AUT C P 25 LU Y, 2000, P 20 COMP INF ENG C MEYERS RJ, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT MINGWU L, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P261 MITCHELL SA, 1997, PERSONAL EXPERIENCE OWEN SJ, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT, P239 OWEN SJ, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG PRICE MA, 1995, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V38, P3335 PRICE MA, 1997, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V40, P111 SAKURAI H, 1996, COMPUT AIDED DESIGN, V28, P519 SCHNEIDERS R, 1995, P 4 INT MESH ROUNDT, P103 SCHNEIDERS R, 1996, ENG COMPUT, V12, P168 SHEFFER A, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT, P347 SHIH BY, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT SONTHI R, 1997, P 4 S SOL MOD APPL S, P285 STATEN ML, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT SUBRAHMANYAM S, 1995, COMPUT IND, V26, P1 TAUTGES TJ, 1996, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V39, P3327 TAUTGES TJ, 1997, FEATURE RECOGNIT AMD, V220 WHITE DR, 1995, P 4 INT MESH ROUNDT, P165 WHITE DR, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P127 WOO TC, 1982, P C CAD CAM MECH ENG, P39; NR: 40; TC: 9; J9: COMPUT AID DES; PG: 12; GA: 405FL

z:row.TitlePrimary: Automatic scheme selection for toolkit hex meshing
z:row.PeriodicalFull: International Journal for Numerical Methods in Engineering
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: W SUSSEX; BAFFINS LANE CHICHESTER, W SUSSEX PO19 1UD, ENGLAND
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Sandia Natl Labs, Albuquerque, NM 87185 USA.; Tautges, TJ, 1500 Johnson Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Current hexahedral mesh generation techniques rely on a set of meshing tools, which when combined with geometry decomposition leads to an adequate mesh generation process. Of these tools, sweeping tends to be the workhorse algorithm, accounting for at least 50 per cent of most meshing applications. Constraints which must be met for a Volume to be sweepable are derived, and it is proven that these constraints are necessary but not sufficient conditions for sweepability. This paper also describes a new algorithm for detecting extruded or sweepable geometries. This algorithm, based on these constraints, uses topological and local geometric information, and is more robust than feature recognition-based algorithms. A method for computing sweep dependencies in volume assemblies is also given. The auto sweep detect and sweep grouping algorithms have been used to reduce interactive user time required to generate all-hexahedral meshes by filtering out non-sweepable volumes needing further decomposition and by allowing concurrent meshing of independent sweep groups. Parts of the auto sweep detect algorithm have also been used to identify independent sweep paths, for use in volume-based interval assignment. Published in 2000 by John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *ANSYS INC, ANSYS *ENT SOFTW PROD IN, FEMAP BLACKER T, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT BLACKER TD, 1994, CUBIT MESH GENERATIO, V1 CASS RJ, 1996, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V39, P1475 FOLWELL NT, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT GILKEY AP, 1994, SAND890485 SAND NAT KNUPP P, PERSONAL EXPERIENCE KNUPP PM, 1999, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V45, P37 LU Y, 2000, IN PRESS COMPUTER AI MINGWU L, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT MINGWU L, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P261 MITCHELL S, 1996, P 13 ANN S THEOR ASP, P465 MORTENSON ME, 1985, GEOMETRIC MODELING MULLERHANNEMANN M, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT RAZDAN A, 1989, VISUAL COMPUT, V5, P291 SCHEFFER A, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT SHEPHERD J, 2000, INT J NUMER METH ENG, V49, P277 STATEN ML, 1998, P 7 INT MESH ROUNDT STEPHENSON MB, 1989, P ASME COMP ENG C SUBRAHMANYAM S, 1995, COMPUT IND, V26, P1 WHITE DR, 1996, P 5 INT MESH ROUNDT; NR: 22; TC: 13; J9: INT J NUMER METHOD ENG; PG: 18; GA: 344MX

z:row.TitlePrimary: Forming and resolving wedges in the spatial twist continuum
z:row.Keyword: hexahedral mesh generation|mesh refinement|plastering|whisker weaving|Computer Science, Interdisciplinary Applications|Engineering, Mechanical
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 175 FIFTH AVE, NEW YORK, NY 10010
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: SANDIA NATL LABS,COMP MECH & VISUALIZAT DEPT,ALBUQUERQUE,NM 87108. FLUID DYNAM INT,EVANSTON,IL. MERCURY MARINE,OSHKOSH,WI. BRIGHAM YOUNG UNIV,PROVO,UT 84602.
z:row.Abstract: The spatial twist continuum (STC) is a powerful extension of the dual of a hexahedral mesh Murdoch et al., Int. J. Numer. Math. Engng (submitted). The STC captures the global connectivity constraints inherent in hexahedral meshing. Whisker weaving is an advancing-front type of algorithm based on the STC [Tautges et al., Int. J. Numer. Math. Engng (submitted]. During the whisker weaving algorithm, certain types of degenerate elements called wedges [Blacker; Myers (1993) Engng with Computers, 9, 83-93 arise. This paper described wedges and how they are formed, and presents collapsing and driving, two strategies for removing these degeneracies.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BLACKER TD, 1993, ENG COMPUT, V9, P83 MURDOCH P, 1995, UNPUB INT J NUMER ME TAUTGES JT, 1995, UNPUB INT J NUMER ME; NR: 3; TC: 0; J9: ENG COMPUT; PG: 13; GA: WK819

z:row.TitlePrimary: The Combination of Data and Functional Partitioning to Parallelize Severe Accident Computer Codes
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: LA GRANGE PK; 555 N KENSINGTON AVENUE, LA GRANGE PK, IL 60525
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.; TAUTGES, TJ, SANDIA NATL LABS,DIV THERMAL HYDRAUL ANAL,POB 5800,ALBUQUERQUE,NM 87185.
z:row.Abstract: Severe accident codes, i. e., codes that model core meltdown and accident progression in light water reactors, do not currently make use of parallel processing technology. Previous efforts to parallelize severe accident codes using DO-loop or data partitioning have resulted in speedup factors of <2.0 because of large serial code sections. Severe accident codes are more amenable to the functional partitioning approach, which splits a code into parallel tasks each representing a separate physical model. When combined, the two methods are able to partition 95% of the HECTR containment analysis code. Overall speedups of 2.6 and 3.2 on four and eight processors are obtained with the parallel HECTR code on an Alliant FX/80 parallel computer when modeling a moderately sized accident scenario. Speed ups are expected to increase for larger severe accident codes, such as MELCOR, which contain more functional parallelism than the HECTR code.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: 1982, MAAP VERSION 3 0 USE 1990, FORGE USERS GUIDE 1990, VECPAR77 TUTORIAL IN AMDAHL G, 1967, 3 P AFIPS SJCC, P483 DINGMAN SE, 1986, NUREGCR4507 SAND NAT DINGMAN SE, 1991, NUREGCR5331 SAND NAT DONGARRA JJ, 1987, CHARACTERISTICS PARA, P363 EAGER DL, 1989, IEEE T COMPUT, V38, P408 ISHIGURO M, 1986, NUCL SCI ENG, V92, P126 LARSON JL, 1984, PRACTICAL CONCERNS M MAKOWITZ H, 1986, NUCL SCI ENG, V92, P136 ORTEGA JM, 1988, PARALLEL COMPUT, V7, P149 OSTERHAUG A, 1987, GUIDE PARALLEL PROGR SASAKI K, 1991, NUCL TECHNOL, V95, P349 SUMMERS RM, 1991, NUREGCR5273 SAND NAT TAUTGES TJ, 1990, THESIS U WISCONSIN M; NR: 16; TC: 1; J9: NUCL SCI ENG; PG: 6; GA: LA496

z:row.TitlePrimary: A Comparison of the Raft and Victoria Computer Codes for Simple Geometries in Chemically Reactive Systems
z:row.Keyword: NUCLEAR AEROSOLS|NUCLEATION|AGGLOMERATION|DEPOSITION|COMPUTER CODES|TELLURIUM|Engineering, Chemical|Engineering, Mechanical|Environmental Sciences|Meteorology & Atmospheric Sciences
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: OXFORD; THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD, ENGLAND OX5 1GB
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT NUCL ENGN & ENGN PHYS,MADISON,WI 53706.; CAPITAO, JA, COMMISS EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES,JOINT RES CTR,I-21020 ISPRA,ITALY.
z:row.Abstract: Two computer codes that predict aerosol formation and transport in the primary circuit of Light Water Reactors are compared for simple problems, to try to establish the main differences between the physical models used in both codes and their effect in predicting severe accident sequences. Besides differences in the nucleation model and in the treatment of chemistry, that are acknowledged by the authors of the codes, important differences in the way the codes treat turbulence were highlighted by this comparison. It is also suggested that the thermochemical databases used for tellurium in the two codes are inconsistent, leading to different predictions of tellurium deposition in the primary circuit.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: FUCHS NA, 1964, MECHANICS AEROSOLS HEAMES TJ, 1990, USNRC CR5545 REP IM KH, 1987, EPRI NP5287CCM REP; NR: 3; TC: 0; J9: J AEROSOL SCI; SU: Suppl. 1; PG: 4; GA: HN118

z:row.Publisher: American Nuclear Society, La Grange Park, IL 60526, United States

z:row.TitlePrimary: Feature based hex meshing methodology: Feature recognition and volume decomposition
z:row.Keyword: Computer aided design|Feature extraction|Finite element method|Mathematical models|Algorithms
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Considerable progress has been made on automatic hexahedral mesh generation in recent years. A few automated meshing algorithms (e.g. mapping, submapping, sweeping) have proven to be very reliable on certain classes of geometry. While it is always worth pursuing general algorithms viable on arbitrary geometry, a combination of the well-established algorithms is ready to take on classes of complicated geometry. By partitioning the entire geometry into meshable pieces matched with appropriate meshing algorithms, the original geometry becomes meshable and may achieve better mesh quality. Each meshable portion is recognized as a meshing feature. This paper, which is a part of the feature based meshing methodology, presents the work on shape recognition and volume decomposition to automatically decompose a CAD model into hex meshable volumes. z:row.TitlePrimary: Multi-component flows in finite difference and control volume approximations on parallel computer architectures
z:row.TitleSecondary: High Performance Computing Symposium 1993. Grand Challenges in Computer Simulation. Proceedings of the 1993 Simulation Multiconference on the High Performance Computing Symposium, 29 March-1 April 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: High Performance Computing Symposium 1993. Grand Challenges in Computer Simulation. Proceedings of the 1993 Simulation Multiconference on the High Performance Computing Symposium
z:row.Keyword: accidents|finite difference methods|fission reactor safety|fission reactor theory and design|nuclear engineering computing|nuclear power stations|parallel architectures|power engineering computing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The risk estimate for nuclear power plants is often based on source term calculations done by computationally intensive severe reactor accident simulations. These fluid dynamics codes balance mass, energy, and momentum over a network of control volumes by solving large, coupled sets of ordinary differential equations. Generally, these codes are not run-time optimized and they take no advantage of the advancements in computer architectures such as vector or parallel processing. Most popular examples of these nuclear accident codes are MELCOR and RELAP5. As parallel computing finds its way into production level industrial real-time applications, one wonders what the best simulation model and best architecture are for nuclear applications. Although far from answering such a question, we have conducted research on the parallel performance of 2 major fluid codes, including a non-nuclear 3-D fluid code (KIVA) in addition to MELCOR and HECTR
z:row.User2: multi-component flow; finite difference approximation; control volume approximations; parallel computer architectures; risk estimate; nuclear power plants; source term calculations; computationally intensive severe reactor accident simulations; fluid dynamics codes; nuclear accident codes; MELCOR; RELAP5; real-time applications; non-nuclear 3-D fluid code; KIVA; HECTR

z:row.TitlePrimary: Radiation-magnetohydrodynamics of plasmas on parallel supercomputers
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fourth Symposium on the Frontiers of Massively Parallel Computation (Cat. No.92CH3185-6), 19-21 Oct. 1992
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fourth Symposium on the Frontiers of Massively Parallel Computation (Cat. No.92CH3185-6)
z:row.Keyword: Boltzmann equation|parallel processing|physics computing|plasma kinetic theory|plasma magnetohydrodynamics|plasma simulation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Center for Parallel Comput. in Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Presents a parallel computational model to simulate plasmas in the radiation-magnetohydrodynamics (R-MHD) framework. The solution of the radiation field usually dominates the R-MHD computation. The authors solve the linear Boltzmann equation for the radiation field intensity, using the deterministic SN discrete ordinates method. Choosing an energy-domain decomposition the authors have implemented the SN method on a parallel processor, the Intel iPSC/860, and the speedups are very favorable. Increasing almost linearly with the number of processors, the speedup reaches 14 on 16 processors. A comparison of timing measurements between a single processor CRAY Y-MP and a 16 processor iPSC/860 implementation strongly favors parallelism by a factor of 3.7
z:row.User2: plasma simulation; parallel computational model; radiation-magnetohydrodynamics; Boltzmann equation; energy-domain decomposition; parallel processor; Intel iPSC/860; speedups
